awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Rethinking the Role of Building Envelopes with Smart Morphing Facades
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to transform building facades from passive structural elements serving their conventional architectural and functional roles to an adaptable engineered system that can (1) protect a building against extreme wind events, (2) reduce safety concerns and structural costs, and (3) eventually contribute to a sustainable solution for energy saving. Traditionally, fixed structures, such as tall buildings, have been designed with a specific shape based on estimates of average wind flow conditions. This appearance-based design can result in shapes that are not the most effective, especially where the wind becomes variable in intensity and direction. To address structural performance issues and achieve an improved safety and comfort for building occupants, this project will develop innovative smart, morphing facade modules that actively modify the building?s aerodynamic shape to alleviate flow-induced vibrations during moderate to high winds. This technology has the potential to be integrated with the growing industry of adaptive facades for energy generation in buildings, providing additional functionality and sustainability benefits. Both graduate and undergraduate students will become involved in this research project, with recruitment that will particularly target students who are underrepresented in engineering fields. The project will also result in new educational engineering activities presented through undergraduate coursework and in STEM outreach to underrepresented and underserved K-12 populations. 

The outcome of this research will result in a new generation of multifunctional morphing facade modules that are sustainable and resilient. Such modules, which have tangible safety and economic benefits, will transform the design of morphing control systems for hazard mitigation purposes. This project will create fundamental knowledge in (1) modeling of the dynamics of tall buildings, taking into consideration the feedback loops for control systems in structural analysis, as well as assessment of the dynamic behavior of the integrated building and active facade; (2) diagnostics of the system properties from observations through pressure, accelerometer, and velocity sensors, where a network of sensors will be used to characterize and reconstruct a near-real-time representation of flow-induced forces acting on the building; and (3) control of the aerodynamic shape of the system to obtain a desired dynamic behavior. This research is expected to advance aerodynamic optimization and active control systems for large-scale morphing surfaces through integrated computational and experimental analyses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The aerodynamic shape of a building is known to impact the wind-induced forces that it experiences during wind excitations. This project developed a novel approach by implementing Smart Morphing Facade (Smorphacade), to reduce the wind load effects on tall buildings. This advanced feature was successfully developed and tested using a feedback loop to capture the response of the structural and facade components. With the active control system incorporated into the developed Smorphacade, the aerodynamic shape of the building can be changed in response to the intensity and direction of the wind excitation according to the target performance level. The research team made notable contributions in three main categories: 1) a new analysis scheme resulted in a set of high-fidelity and high-efficiency analysis algorithms that capture morphing concepts. To characterize the interactions of the building as a bluff body with its surrounding flow, wind effects were systematically characterized using self-excited loads in the three-degree-of-freedom response analysis of the building in along-wind, across-wind, and torsional directions. The wind loads on a building in the time domain were calculated by combining both the buffeting and self-excited loads. These time-domain aerodynamic force formulations are not only useful for this project but can also be used for modeling and simulation, feedback-dependent structural control, fatigue-life prediction, and, above all, transient structural response during nonstationary wind excitations, such as gusts, tornadoes, and microbursts; 2) tests on buildings with Smorphacades were performed on aeroelastic models (1:175 and 1:75 geometric scale) of the Commonwealth Advisory Aeronautical Research Council Coordinators (CAARC) standard tall building under atmospheric boundary layer winds. The Smorphacade setups consisted of a set of circular ducts arranged in a matrix format attached to the original façade comprised of two parts: (i) a fixed base with alternate open and closed surfaces shaped like a stationary fan blade and (ii) a rotating part placed inside the fixed one (with a similar shape) that could be rotated by a protruding fin about its center (rotating fan). By rotating the fin, it became possible to simultaneously adjust the porosity of the duct and the fin inclination angle, enabling control of flow through the duct. The performance of Smorphacade was studied in a range of configurations; 3) a new control system based on a gated recurrent unit (GRU) encoder-decoder model was developed. Time-series readings from a network of sensors (accelerometers, pressure probes, encoders, and atmospheric pressure) were fed to the encoder GRU, which constructed a unique internal representation (hidden state) of the evolving physical system. The decoder GRU used this hidden state, along with possible facade orientations, to predict future building motion. A sequential genetic algorithm optimization procedure used the trained encoder-decoder GRU as a surrogate plant model to determine optimum facade orientations that minimize wind-induced vibration in the future.

The extensive analytical and experimental investigations were specifically geared toward the mitigation of wind hazards and improving the building occupant comfort. The project outcomes showed that Smorphacade can decrease the wind-induced loading demand on buildings by more than 40%, which greatly improves the safety, performance, and economy of buildings. Such tangible advantages, combined with the growing industry of adaptive facades, promotes a major leap forward in resilient and sustainable cities and has the potential to positively impact the involved industries.
